awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Watershed, estuarine, and local drivers of coastal marsh establishment and resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
Salt marshes provide numerous ecosystem services including shoreline protection, nutrient cycling, pollutant filtration, nurseries for fish and crustaceans, food production, recreation, and carbon sequestration. Coastal wetlands have been degraded and lost because of changes to upland and coastal environments, and future sea-level rise threatens to exacerbate these trends. This project will advance scientific understanding of the mechanisms that influence marsh formation, persistence, and degradation, which is essential to forecasting future wetland change. The project aims to develop a new way to analyze the vulnerability of marshes that will be relevant to decision-making. Through a student-organized symposium, the work will be communicated directly to policy-makers and practitioners of marsh conservation and restoration. This project will advance science teaching and education both through training the next generation of university students and working with youth in local high schools.
 
Coastal wetlands are complex biogeomorphic systems that provide important ecosystem services, but our current understanding of salt marsh evolution and projections of future changes are based on models and empirical studies of limited spatial and temporal extent. In this project, the team asks "what determines the present, continental-scale extent and distribution of coastal marshes"? They hypothesize that marsh distributions reflect interactions across a wide range of spatial scales, including local biogeomorphic feedbacks, estuarine-scale morphology that governs sediment gradients and wave energy, and past and present watershed processes that influence sediment and water flux. The team proposes an integrated theoretical and empirical approach that takes advantage of continental-scale variation in watershed and estuarine characteristics to understand (1) when, where, and how salt marshes have established, and (2) how marsh distributions respond to sea-level rise, altered suspended sediment concentrations, and other environmental changes.

por.por_cntn:
Coastal marshes provide important ecosystem services, and are threatened by local and global environmental changes including land use, river impoundment, and sea level rise. In some cases, marshes survive sea level rise by building their soil vertically so that their plants remain above water. However, there are vigorous scientific debates over the rate of sea level rise that a marsh can survive, and the various factors that influence vertical accretion of marsh soils. In this project, we measured the maximum rate of vertical accretion for salt marshes in 4 estuaries on the Atlantic Coast of the United States, and measured how much mineral sediment was available for soil growth in the waters flooding the marshes. We also reviewed the scientific literature to assess sediment supply and marsh accretion for 70 marshes around the globe to see if our local observations could be extended to understand the limits of marsh accretion more generally. Our research found a strong link between maximum rates of vertical accretion and sediment supply, and demonstrated unequivocally that marsh vulnerability to SLR is determined by mineral sediment supply at regional-continental scales. However, it also pointed to strong gradients in sediment supply within marshes, and high variability in marsh vulnerability between sites. For example, we discovered that sedimentation on a salt marsh is largely decoupled from the availability of sediment in adjacent tidal channels. Because sediment supply is typically measured in tidal channels, our work suggests that numerical models and traditional field-based metrics may overestimate marsh adaptability. Nevertheless, our work demonstrates that numerical models can predict upper limits of marsh accretion at regional-continental scales. 

This work is important for our understanding of coastal ecosystems to sea level rise and human alterations of watersheds, as well as to our understanding of tipping points and resilience of ecosystems to changing environmental conditions.  To promote more effective management of coastal systems, we presented the work at several stakeholder meetings that included landowners, policy makers, and conservation groups. To promote general education, we presented the work to a local homeschool co-op group, developed lesson plans for secondary school students, led field trips for community college students, lectured to adult continuing education classes, and discussed the results of our work in local and national media.
